elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about the letters
, engage children with an activity, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
What things do the brothers argue about?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Use information to compare and contrast.
Identify at least 20 uppercase and at least 20 lowercase letters in isolation.
Recognize and  produce words that have the same beginning sound.
Identify that there is meaning in text.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
What can we learn from using our senses?
What part of your body do you use when you listen to stories?
What do you use to smell what you make when you pretend you are cooking in the kitchen area?
What color are the counters? What do you use to see the color?
Draw something you would like to smell. Can you add a label?
What materials can you use to make something bumpy? Soft?
Look at the Alphabet Cards for
. Can you write each letter in the sand tray?
Can you build a long snake with blocks? Show me.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder focus attention, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to notice and talk about when children are focusing their attention.
Use information to compare and contrast.
Identify that there is meaning in text.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Invite children to identify which letter card is missing.
Encourage children to place the missing letter back where it belongs.
What can we learn from using our senses?
How do you use your eyes to read a book?
Pretend you are making dinner for your friends. What would you make? How would it taste?
Show me something that feels smooth. Show me something that feels rough.
What is your favorite thing to taste? Draw a picture and write the word.
Can you make a tree? How can you make the bark look bumpy?
Can you build a road? What do you hear when cars ride on it?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to tap into prior knowledge and build background, engage children with a song, and introduce vocabulary
Which boy do you think is right?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Use pre-reading skills in self-selected books.
Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Discuss with children how to hold and care for books.
Ask children to tell about the book they chose.
What can we learn from using our senses?
Choose a book. What do you see that makes you want to choose that book?
Pretend you are on the phone. What do you hear with your ears?
Connect some Connecting Cubes. Touch and count them.
Draw a picture of yourself reading a book.
You read about crickets singing in the night. Can you use these materials to make a cricket?
with finger paint. What words start with the letter
? What words start with the letter
Can you build a house with your eyes closed? What can you use to help you feel the blocks?

attributes.alt:
Big Chart of Big Ideas for See! Hear! Taste! Smell! And Touch! Chart shows a young boy with arrows pointing to different senses.
Bubbles point to different parts of the boy’s body:
-   Bubble next to boy’s eye says "What can I use my eyes to see?"
-   Bubble next to boy’s tongue says "What can I use my tongue to taste?"-   Bubble next to boy’s nose says "What can I use my nose to smell?"
-   Bubble next to boy’s ear says "What can I use my ears to hear?"
-   Bubble next to boy’s hand says "What can I use my hand to touch?"

elements.text: See! Hear! Taste! Smell! and Touch!
Use Circle Time to talk about the five senses, engage children with a song, and introduce vocabulary
See! Hear! Taste! Smell! and Touch!
Read closely to answer the weekly concept question:
What can we learn from using our senses?
Relate own experiences to those in books.
Identify that there is meaning in text.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
Provide mystery boxes with items, such as a bell, cotton balls, cinnamon stick, and/or a picture, for children to discover using one sense at a time.
Discuss which sense was used to explore each item.
What can we learn from using our senses?
Close your eyes and listen to a story. How is it different from when you look at the pictures while you listen?
Use Connecting Cubes to make three trains. Put them in order to show the short, shorter, and shortest trains.
Look out the classroom window. Can you draw and write about what you see?
Create something that feels good when you touch it.
How are they the same? Different?
Can you build three buildings? Can you put them in order to show tall, taller, and tallest?

TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Close Your Eyes by Victoria Pérez, illustrated by Claudia Ranucci. Text copyright © 2009 by Victoria Pérez. elements.text: Use Circle Time to have children celebrate their senses by participating in scarf dancing and to introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking,
How do our senses help us learn?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share and repeat the details in a text.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
React to a variety of musical styles through movement and play.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
Describe how you used all of your senses today.
Save children’s writing to display next week.
What can we learn from using our senses?
Pretend you are the teacher and show and tell about a book.
Pretend you are a scientist. Can you use your senses to explore these buttons/rocks?
Find three things you would put in a mystery box that would be fun to touch.
Draw and write about one way in which you used your sense of hearing today.
Use the play clay to create a shape that’s interesting to look at and touch.
What sound do you hear at the beginning of
? Can you draw a kite and write the letter
What kind of structure can you create with the blocks?
